title: One-armed, one-legged retired British teacher found dead in boot of car in Italy with his throat cut
text:
The retired teacher had lived in Italy for 35 years (Photo: Google Maps) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A retired British teacher with only one arm and one leg was found dead in the boot of a car with his throat slashed. 
Mystery surrounds the final movements of Richard Anthony Collinssplatt, 77, as police in Italy try to piece together how he came to be found with razor-blade injuries and carbon monoxide in his blood. 
He was found in the boot of his Nissan Micra in his garage in Pavullo, near the Italian city of Modena, on March 10. 
Mr Collinssplatt, who lived in Italy for more than 35 years and taught English, lost his leg in a car crash as a young man and a horse riding accident claimed his arm many years later. 
Prosecutors are investigating whether it is a case of murder or suicide, according to Italian publication Gazzetta di Modena . Italian police are investigating the case (Photo: Getty) Read More Police quiz 'secret lover' of British UFO conspiracy theorist who died after vomiting two litres of black fluid 
Many circumstances surrounding the death are unexplained and police have not ruled out the possibility of foul play. 
It is reported there were "several superficial wounds" on Mr Collinssplatt's body that were "attributable to a razor blade", with the longest cut on his throat. 
A razor blade capable of inflicting the injuries was reportedly found in the car. 
But detectives are baffled by the lack of blood on the vehicle's ignition and door handles. 
It is not clear how Mr Collinssplatt was able to shut himself inside the boot while injured so badly and without his prosthetic limbs. Mr Collinssplatt died in Pavullo, northern Italy (Photo: Google Maps) Read More Goa backpacker murder: The missing 10 hours that could hold clue to solving 'gang-rape killing' of Danielle McLaughlin 
There was also carbon monoxide in his bloodstream that must have been breathed in before he died, according to the prosecutor's office. 
But Timothy Keates, a close friend of Mr Collinssplatt and a fellow expat, said he could not believe the retired teacher had killed himself. 
He told The Times: "I never saw him depressed and he never complained about his disability. I saw him three days before he died and the last thing he said was 'when it gets warmer we will have a barbecue in my garden'. That is not someone who commits suicide." 
Forensic tests are continuing to establish the exact circumstances of his death. Like us on Facebook
